I just want to clarify my suggestion.

Minecraft should include a Legacy World Mode for old MCPE worlds (such as those from version 1.0.6 or earlier). When converting these worlds to Bedrock Edition, the game should:

‚Ä¢ Preserve all existing blocks exactly as they were
‚Ä¢ Generate new terrain using the same style as MCPE, not modern Bedrock
‚Ä¢ Allow access to new blocks and features without disrupting the original biome structure
‚Ä¢ Recognize that the world comes from an older version and make an ‚Äúexception‚Äù in how it is handled

This would allow players to continue exploring their old worlds as if they were still playing on MCPE ‚Äì but with all the benefits of modern Bedrock Edition. Most importantly, the buildings and creations that players have worked on for years would remain untouched and completely intact.

I think this could be a feature that's not default, or simply an accessibility feature. The game will pretty much be harder when using wasd, probably even harder than using a controller, since it become rather hard to aim at something. As for game balancing, i don't think things will change that much, it can be that both wasd and mouse can be used at the same time, and it's pretty common that, when you are attacking, you are forced to stand still, especially for ranged attack. MCD isn't a twin stick shooter, i mean. Though i also don't think that allowing twin stick shooting would cause much game balancing issue as well, and that could probably make it possible for two person to play the same character together, and that can allow more people to enjoy the game.

On a side note, for anyone finding it tiring to play with a mouse, try a trackball -- you will still click a lot but your wrist won't go sour anymore. Not exactly easy to get into though, but it might worth trying.

Before the game launched, I was astonished that there was no level editor. For me, this is a large detractor.

Also: a custom level workshop similar to Steam would be desirable and add a great deal to the game. This would also work really well with the ability to pair custom textures and other assets with maps.

Having four different kinds of levels you can create that each have a maximum for things like chests or pots, and a minimum for things like bosses and enemies such as:

   Normal- The standard level type, has a medium amount of allowed chests/pots, and a medium requirement for enemies, and no limits on bosses, with average loot.

   Secret- Similar to the normal type, but with a slightly lower enemie requirement and chest/pot limit and can be unlocked in all normal/boss levels.

   Boss- Counts as a boss level for apocalypse+ and has higher requirements and better loot, as well as more chests/pots and harder enemies.

   Freestyle- A level with no limits, however anything that happens in the level doesn't actually save to your character to prevent it from being OP.
